subject: RE: [junit] Testing an interface with JUnit
msgSnippet: You can use JUnit to help enforce the interface contract: eg A stack interface has push,pop - as well as defining these methods you also might want to define
messageBody:
You can use JUnit to help enforce the interface contract:
eg
A stack interface has push,pop - as well as defining these methods you also
might want to define the behaviour
eg
an object pushed onto the stack is then retrieved by the pop method..

Ive done this using an abstract test case (see code below):

An implimentation of the Stack interface must then extend this test case,
overwriting the setUp() to instantiate the Stack objects with the
implementation type..

This test case then becomes usable by all implmenetors of the interface..



--
Remember there is more to the interface than just the method signatures,
there can also be some definition of behaviour, unit tests can help with
this..
--
After an argument the other night in a bar with a friend I had to conceeed
that documentation can also perform this role..;-)


public abstract class TestStack extends TestCase {

public TestStack(String name) {
super(name);
}

//the following must be created by subclasses
protected Stack fullStack; //a stack with items in
protected Stack emptyStack; //an empty stack


public void testPushAndPop() {
//last in - first out
fullStack.push("first");
fullStack.push("middle");
fullStack.push("last");

Object out;

out = fullStack.pop();
assertEquals(out, "last");
out = fullStack.pop();
assertEquals(out, "middle");
out = fullStack.pop();
assertEquals(out, "first");
}

public void testPop() {
//throws exception when empty
try {
emptyStack.pop();
fail("Should raise NoSuchElementException");
}
catch (NoSuchElementException nsee) {
}


}


/**
* Tests the isEmpty function work as expected
*/
public void testIsEmpty() {
//basics
assertTrue(emptyStack.isEmpty());
assertTrue(!fullStack.isEmpty());

//empty stack->push->not empty
emptyStack.push("String");
assertTrue(!emptyStack.isEmpty());

//stack with one item->pop->is empty
emptyStack.pop();
assertTrue(emptyStack.isEmpty());

}
}

> If you mean a java interface, then you don't test those. You
> test an _implementation_ of an interface.
>
> A mock object, easymock or otherwise, is a way of testing the
> _clients_ of an interface by substituting an alternative
> implementation. There are interesting trade-offs for the
> various techniques for implementing mock objects.
